title: Is It a Gallbladder Attack?

content: If you’ve ever had a gallbladder attack, you know that it feels like your entire digestive system is under assault. I’ve never experienced a gallbladder attack, but I’ve witnessed two in the same person. Here’s why gallbladder attacks happen and how to prevent them.

The gallbladder is a small, pear-shaped organ that stores bile. Bile is made mostly of water, cholesterol, bile salts — which are derived from cholesterol, and bilirubin, a yellow-orange pigment that results from the breakdown of old red blood cells.
Bile is needed to digest fat. The liver constantly makes bile and stores it in the gallbladder. When you eat, the gallbladder releases bile into the small intestine.
Bile ducts transport bile from the gallbladder to the small intestine during digestion. Problems happen when gallstones, which come in a range of sizes, form in the gallbladder.

A gallbladder attack happens when gallstones make their way into the bile ducts and block the normal flow of bile, resulting in sudden pain in your right upper abdomen. Attacks typically occur after a high-fat meal, when the gallbladder is called upon to release more bile.

content: Gallbladder attacks usually pass when the gallstones move and stop blocking the bile ducts. However, if you’ve had one gallbladder attack, you’ll likely have more.

Gallstones affect 10% to 15% of the U.S. population, which is nearly 25 million people. Anyone can have gallstones that cause gallbladder attacks, but there are several known risk factors for the condition.

Elevated cholesterol levels in the bloodstream. Most gallstones are cholesterol stones. Following a balanced diet that’s low in saturated fat can help to keep blood cholesterol levels within a normal range to help prevent gallstone formation. Saturated fat, found in fatty meats, cheese, butter, and coconut oil, raises cholesterol levels in the blood.

Focus on soluble fiber. Soluble fiber, found in foods such as oats, lentils, legumes, and berries, helps to keep blood cholesterol levels in the normal range. Aim for a total of 25 to 38 grams of fiber daily to include the soluble fiber you need.

sections.heading: Being overweight or having obesity
content: . Excess weight is associated with a greater risk for gallstones, especially in women. Having obesity is a risk factor for higher blood cholesterol levels, which contribute to the formation of gallstones. In addition, those with obesity may also have larger gallbladders that don’t function properly.

If you keep having gallbladder attacks, it’s best to remove the gallbladder. Gallbladder removal surgery is typically a minimally invasive procedure and is one of the most common operations done on adults to treat gallbladder attacks, although doctors use nonsurgical treatments for gallstones in special situations, including if you have a serious medical condition that prevents surgery.

The good news is that it’s possible to digest fat without a gallbladder. Your liver still produces bile, but instead of sending it to the gallbladder for storage, it releases bile directly into the small intestine. You don’t need to follow a special diet after you have your gallbladder removed, but it never hurts to follow a balanced eating plan and maintain a healthy weight to support gut health and overall well-being.
